node.title: ACMultiInterface kernel: kappa as a function of a variable?
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I'm trying to implement the ACMultiInterface kernel in a 3-phase system and I would like the kappa terms to be functions of a separate order parameter (a different one than the "eta" order parameters from the interface). If a kappa term is defined as a DerivativeParsedMaterial as a function of theta (for example), will the changing value of kappa with theta be reflected in the ACMultiInterface kernel? And more importantly, will the ACMultiInterface kernel include the gradient of theta as it computes the divergence of the interface terms? If using a kappa term as a function of another variable is not possible, is there a workaround to get an equivalent effect?
Thanks,
Scott

It's not clear to me what you are trying to implement here. Could you please elaborate on the model/formulation? Kernels associated with basic phase-field equations terms are provided here, https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Phase_Field_Equations.html
You can also check out ACKappaFunction  which considers the derivative of the kappa term.

Thank you for the response. I'm trying to implement a non-isothermal system with three distinct non-conserved phases, each of which has its own order parameter (representing the phase volume fraction),
Variables:
Order parameters: phi_1, phi_2, phi_3
Temperature: T

For brevity, I'll use phi_q to reference the order parameters in this outline. The free energy is a combination of thermodynamic terms (heat capacity and latent heat with phase changes) and coupled interface terms that may be different between any two phases,
Free Energy:
f(phi_q,T) = f_bulk(phi_q,T) + f_interface(phi_q,grad(phi_q))
f_bulk(phi_q,T) = h(phi_1)*f_1(T) + h(phi_2)*f_2(T) + h(phi_3)*f_3(T)
f_interface(phi_q,grad(phi_q)) = f_dw(phi_q) + f_grad(phi_q,grad(phi_q))

I felt the ACMultiInterface kernel was most appropriate for f_grad as it handles the complex cross terms between each pair of order parameters and their gradients. I use a CrossTermBarrierFunctionMaterial for the double-well term f_dw. The evolution equations for the order parameters are then straightforward,
Evolution equation for order parameter q:
dphi_q/dt + L*df/dphi_q + penalty = 0 ;  q={1,2,3}

The challenge comes in deriving an evolution equation for temperature. The internal energy can be derived as
Internal energy:
e(phi_q,T) = f(phi_q,T) - T*df/dT = e_bulk(phi_q,T) + f_interface(phi_q,grad(phi_q))

Note that the interface term is unchanged in this transformation because df_interface/dT = 0. The time evolution for temperature, with thermal conductivity k, can be expressed as,
Evolution equation for T:
de/dT*dT/dt + sum(de/dphi_q*dphi_q/dt + de/d(grad(phi_q))*d(grad(phi_q))/dt,q={1,2,3}) - div(k(phi_q)*grad(T)) = 0

I'm not positive that the grad(phi_q) terms needs to be included here, but I don't feel that I can discard them out of hand. Even if I could, the de/dphi_q terms are themselves quite complicated as they must include portions of the cross terms from f_interface. It may be that the effect of these terms is negligible enough that they can safely be discarded, but I would have to actually set it up in order to verify it, which is what I hope to avoid.
To dramatically simplify this problem I could recast f_interface as being a linear function of T. The internal energy would then simply be e(phi_q,T) = e_bulk(phi_q,T) and the evolution equation for T would become
Recast internal energy and evolution equation for T:
de_bulk/dT*dT/dt + sum(de_bulk/dphi_q*dphi_q/dt,q={1,2,3}) - div(k(phi_q)*grad(T)) = 0

Here the de_bulk/dphi_q terms are very straightforward. This modified formulation seems mathematically complete to me, and much less taxing computationally. I had hoped to implement it by making the kappa term in the ACMultiInterface kernel a simple linear function of T, but it doesn't seem to be a built-in option, hence my question.
The ACKappaFunction you suggested looks promising. I suppose I would use a different ACKappaFunction for each kappa value for a given order parameter. Does that sound right? Looking at ACMultiInterface, do you have any reason to think it can't be used with multiple kappa values each defined by their own ACKappaFunction? Please let me know if you have any other ideas or suggestions. Also, please let me know if you see a problem with my formulation or approach in general. Thanks again for your help!
-Scott

In the 4th equation on https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/kernels/ACMultiInterface.html you can see that we pulled out Kappa, assuming that it is constant (i.e. has a vanishing gradient). This is consistent with the code in modules/phase_field/src/kernels/ACMultiInterface.C, where no derivatives of the kappas are used.
For your application you'd have to redo the derivation and implement the resulting weak form containing the dkappa/dvar derivatives for all variables your kappas depend on (to construct grad(kappa) = sum(grad(var)*dkappa/dvar).

That makes sense, and answers my original question. Thanks!
I'm probably overthinking it. The literature I've reviewed so far doesn't bother including interfacial energy terms with their internal energy when deriving temperature evolution equations for non-isothermal systems. Most seem to treat internal energy as a bulk quantity. I'm not fully convinced and would love to see a justification one way or another. I'd be grateful if you have any other advice related to my problem, or any related literature that deals with it more explicitly.
-Scott

node.title: libmesh update
node.bodyText:
All, we've had a couple of libmesh updates make their way into moose master and into the conda channels in relatively close succession.
Here are a summary of the changes:

Mimic stl and boost constructors in our allocators
Try changing max order for L2 families
Add LumpedMassMatrix class
Test custom FE reinit
$LIBMESH_BENCHMARK selection of benchmarking examples
RB: skip reinit when there are no DOFs on Elem
Command-line override of default Metis-vs-Parmetis
init_names() at more points
Fix FE side unit tests with --enable-complex
Begin contains_vertex_of with node equality tests
chunked_mapvector storage option
Weaken partitioner_test for SFC on 8+ processors
Bugfix for PR libMesh/libmesh#2940
Revert "interior_parent fix on distributed refined multi-elem_dim meshes"
interior_parent fix on distributed refined multi-elem_dim meshes
RB EIM update
Fix for deprecated warning in SLEPc not-quite-3.15
Use pool allocator in mapvector
Check for gdb in command line in print_trace when compiling with no gdb backtrace by default
Add a new functor for sync element integers
Some cleanup for RB EIM code
edgeset/nodeset/sideset unit test refactor
More contains_vertex_of optimization
Fix distributed p coarsening assertion

node.title: Name of selected MooseEnum item
node.bodyText:
I would like to use the name (string) of an item selected in a MooseEnum to be a suffix as part of another name.  Let me try to explain.  Given the declaration:
   const field::FieldEnum _field;

and the initialization in a Material constructor:
   _field(getParam<MooseEnum>("field").getEnum<field::FieldEnum>()),

I would then like to declare a property like:
   _alfa(declareADProperty<Real>("alfa_" + name_of(_field_)),

where name_of(_field) would be the name associated with the MooseEnum item _field.  _field is (of course) an integer and I have been unable to find how to get the associated name.  I am sure this is due to my minimal understanding of MooseEnum.
Thanks for the help,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
First do you need to do this:
_field(getParam("field").getEnumfield::FieldEnum())
Or could you get by with
_field(getParam<MooseEnum>("field")),
?
This field enum is a structure you declared right? It inherits from MooseEnum right?
You want to use the name() attribute of the enumerated objects. You could retrieve the name using the MooseEnumBase::find(int ...) routine with _field. This might not be the most graceful way though.
Guillaume
I got the getNames() option to work.  Thanks!

just do
_field_name(getParam<MooseEnum>("field"))

in your initializer list, where _field_name is a const std::string member.

Thanks Dan.  Could you please mark this as answered?
Joe

node.title: [Peacock][Windows10]
node.bodyText:
Dear moose users,
Is there any method to use peacock in windows 10?
I used ubuntu as an app in windows 10 and used Paraview to analyze output files.
But, I found a bug in Paraview to analyze my data, so I want to use Peacock to analyze my data.
If it's not possible, then I will use a virtual machine or dual booting of windows and Linux...
Best regards,
Nakkyu

hello
As mentioned here, you will see some artefacts when using peacock on WSL with windows 10.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/windows10.html
But it should launch, using the X-server for visualization
Guillaume
I ‘ve met the same question too.

node.title: peacock error
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose expert and user,
I try to execute the input file in peacock. The following error appears. I have no idea what happened. Before I succeeded in implementing the same file in peacock and everything is fine. But I failed when performing execution again.

Thank you for your help.

Hello
This looks like a missing python package error.
Looks like you have activated the moose environment so that's good. Could you please try updating moose and its dependencies?
So conda update --all then git fetch upstream, git rebase upstream/devel OR git checkout upstream/devel depending on whether you are developing or just using.
Guillaume

@GiudGiud. Thanks. I try it according to your instruction. One message shows below when trying 'git fetch upstream'.

Any advices? Thank you.
The remote is probably called origin not upstream on your machine

@GiudGiud is correct, you are just missing a python package. Be sure your conda enviroment has "moose-tools" installed, it will give you all the packages needed for Peacock. Running conda list will show if it is there or not.

The remote is probably called origin not upstream on your machine

@GiudGiud Thanks. After updating conda, when I try 'git checkout origin/devel', the message below was got. Any advice? Thank you.

@GiudGiud is correct, you are just missing a python package. Be sure your conda enviroment has "moose-tools" installed, it will give you all the packages needed for Peacock. Running conda list will show if it is there or not.

Hi @aeslaughter Thank you. I use 'conda list' to confirm there is the moose-tools. But peacock is still not working and shows same error.

Well updating moose might not be as critical.
If you want to do it anyway:
It looks like there are some merge conflicts. You ll have to either deal with those or just get rid of your changes (git stash) before checking out the latest moose
The ciritical thing here is that your moose-tools package is severely outdated.
Please follow the instructions in this post to delete and re-install the moose environment: #18378
pasted here:
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n moose
conda install mamba
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
conda activate moose

Well updating moose might not be as critical.
If you want to do it anyway:
It looks like there are some merge conflicts. You ll have to either deal with those or just get rid of your changes (git stash) before checking out the latest moose
The ciritical thing here is that your moose-tools package is severely outdated.
Please follow the instructions in this post to delete and re-install the moose environment: #18378
pasted here:
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n moose
conda install mamba
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
conda activate moose


@GiudGiud Thank you. It works well now.

node.title: Cubit meshing a few elements manually / meshing a weird sector region
node.bodyText:
Is there a way in Cubit to mesh a few elements manually?
Do I need to specify just a single volume = 1 element and be careful that the volume shape corresponds to an element?
If I create a few elements manually, should I:

do this region first and the other volumes will pick up on the nodes I created
do this region last and use the nodes created by the other regions (how do I retrieve them then?)

Alternatively, does anyone know a scheme that can mesh this, and connect with the hex mesh volumes nearby
Here's a closeup on the volume (orange) I'm trying to mesh. It's an open source model.

Additional details on the mesh:

2D surfaces revolved using the sweep (0 steps in angle) to create 3D volumes
3D volumes meshed directly using the auto scheme

Thanks!
Guillaume

In your picture, it looks like the orange volume is "pyramidal" in shape... would you be able to share the .cub file?  If it is, in fact pyramidal, Cubit doesn't have a built-in method for meshing it with hexes (though you could tetmesh it, then thex it into hexes...).  Meshing a pyramid is the great challenge in hex-meshing, look up "Schneider's Pyramid".
One option may be to build a mixed-mesh on that volume - essentially building a pyramid-tet mesh on the orange volume that interfaces with the hex elements on the neighboring volumes.  If your volumes are imprinted & merged, trying doing the following:
vol {orange_volume_id} scheme tetmesh
mesh volume {orange_volume_id} 

One general comment regarding meshing, not necessarily specific to Cubit is that you should mesh the "most constrained" regions of your model first.  And then mesh the "next most constrained" (which are often the neighbors of the most-constrained regions) and so on.

Hello
cub file attached.
I would be fine with a single tet/pyramid at the top of the pyramid and the rest being hexes.
Is there an easy way to do that or should I just cut the top of the pyramid into one block?
Is there a way to ask for a pyramid mesh cell?
I ll try the test mesh -> hex route now
fhr_core.zip
Thanks for the advice on the ordering of the mesh. I ll definitely do that once I can get a coarse-ish hex mesh for that volume.

One issue with the tet mesh is that the elements are really small, and only get smaller with the THex operation. I tried to set a really large size for the initial mesh. Should I define intervals on the curves instead?
    cubit.cmd('volume 8 size 20')
    cubit.cmd('volume 8 scheme Tetmesh')
    cubit.cmd('mesh volume 8')
    cubit.cmd('THex volume 8')

See attached meshed geometry.
fhr_core_meshed.zip
Here are the cubit commands that I did:
open "fhr_core.cub"

## All volumes, except for the challenge volume, are already meshed
## The surfaces of the challenge volume that are shared with neighboring, meshed volumes, are also meshed (with quads)
## We want to mesh the unmeshed surfaces of the challenge volume with triangles
surface 38 37 8  scheme trimesh geometry approximation angle 15 
Trimesher surface gradation 1.3
Trimesher geometry sizing on
mesh surface 38 37 8 

## Mesh the challenge region with the tetmesh scheme, resulting in a pyramid-to-tet mesh
volume 8  scheme tetmesh
mesh volume 8 

In the below image: tet elements are green, pyramid are yellow, hexes are magenta

And detail of the challenge volume:


The tetmesh scheme in Cubit is from the 3D Precise Mesh library licensed from Dassault, which they acquired from Distene (library was Distene MeshGems).  The tet meshing library that they provide will automatically produce a mixed tet-pyramid mesh if the input volume has even a single quad element within its bounding surfaces.
More information
The reason this was challenging is because you have a pyramid-like volume (grey).  In this below picture, you made a webcut (highlighted) that resulted in this volume's shape/topology:

You additionally assigned a block that only contained this exact volume.  This is likely intentional -- you may have a body-load or material assignment that needs to take up this exact region.  However, if you didn't mean to have this be a separate block, and it could be united with the blue volume below it, then you could generate a mesh more easily as the resulting body would be prism-like (and thus sweepable):


Notice how we've effectively relaxed a constraint on the mesh, which makes it easier to hex-mesh.  This may not be a constraint you're able to relax, but it hopefully shows that sometimes "less is more".

Thanks for the detailed reply. I was trying to cut the volumes into smaller chunks to make it easier to mesh / narrow down the problem to a single region. We are actually able to relax that constraint.
We are good with this mesh now. Thanks a lot for helping out.

Hello
What is the boundary specified for c_liquid_inlet?
The output log should tell us if it does exist.
Guillaume

@rtaylo45 To add onto this– if you are using the mesh generated from SAM ex01, were you attempting to set a BC at the inlet? The inlet/outlet sidesets may not actually be named for 1D fluid components, you can try using boundary = 0 for the inlet but I haven't tried this myself.
@travismui yes i am using ex01 to generate this mesh. Adding boundary = 0 for the inlet and boundary = 1 for the outlet fixed my problem.

node.title: How to push to large_media
node.bodyText: I have some large media files that belong in the large_media submodule as part of PR #17475 .  It's a submodule so don't I have to first update the large_media repository and then update my ref to it in moose?  If so how can I submit changes to large_media?

Oh sorry I thought I replied to you in that PR but it turns out I never hit that "comment" button...
Anyways, I think you should submit a PR to large_media. @aeslaughter or someone else with write access will merge it. Then you can update the large media commit in your moose PR.
Thanks.  I don't see any PRs on github against large_media but maybe I'm just the first person in awhile to not have direct write access that wants to add something.

The repository is here: https://github.com/idaholab/large_media
There have been 16 closed PRs already.
At least I don't have write access to it either 😃
Fair enough, I opened the PR.

node.title: *** ERROR *** Cannot allocate a NumericVector
node.bodyText:
I was trying to run a large 3D grain growth simulation  (3D_6000_gr.i)  and I am getting following error

*** ERROR ***
Cannot allocate a NumericVector with 3224060050 degrees of freedom. The vector can only index up to 2147483647 entries.



MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 60 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.


NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.

My mesh block is shown here
[Mesh]
  [gmg]
    type = DistributedRectilinearMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    nx = 400
    ny = 400
    nz = 400
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 400
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 400
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 400
    elem_type = HEX8
  []
   parallel_type = distributed
[]

I am using 50 order parameters and 20K grains. In the past #17422, I did not face this issue. (I was using different HPC for this case.)
I tried following steps: 1) update Libmesh and MOOSE; 2) Install new MOOSE; and 3) Install new Moose with ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh option (our HPC has installed PETSc for us). I am getting same error.
Any suggestions?
Thank you very much.
Kind regards
Vishal Yadav

Hello
This should have worked..
This error should be linked to the petsc indexing scheme, and since you ran update_and_rebuild_petsc, this should have been using 64 bit indices.
Could you please check that script, update_and_rebuild_petsc and see if the  --with-64-bit-indices is present in the ./configure call for petsc
Guillaume

Thank  you @GiudGiud !
This suggestion worked.  Now, I can start this simulation.

node.title: Segmentation Fault when running input file from terminal
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I'm getting the following segmentation fault error, I checked with gdb and this is what I got:
Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x00007ffff7ef9ff7 in xxxMaterial::validParams ()
Does it have to with my code, or is it something else? I can't seem to figure it out, as the fault is occurring before anything is even done (line 8). All my required material properties are initialized in the input file, so I don't have any idea what else could be causing this. I'm using Ubuntu 20.04 on Windows (WSL).

hello
If you using gdb could you please provide us with the backtrace then?
If you could build in debug mode (METHOD=dbg make) first, that would help since it ll give the exact line of the set fault.
Alternatively, you could run valgrind and it ll point out where the memory error happened
Best
Guillaume

Thanks, I was able to figure it out with the backtrace, I didn't know about that before. Also, a quick question: I'm automatically calculating the Jacobian instead of doing it manually, because it's a system of 4 coupled PDEs. It converged and it's pretty convenient, but I was wondering why I'm getting this output on the terminal

I usually get "neatly arranged" tables while it's solving, but I guess it's fine since I still get a good result. This just threw me off at first.
This looks like you have a print statement somewhere. Like in a kernel or a material property. And it s flooding the console output
Look for "std::cout", "std::cerr" lines
I'd hazard a guess that it's your "xxxMaterial": look in the validParams() function.
